rev.comment: they don't reject it, they simply use a different system (in fact, they even support FHS with kernel patches)
rev.diff:
Line 6: Line 6:
The FHS is maintained by the [[Free Standards Group]], a non-profit organization consisting of major software and hardware vendors, such as [[HP]], [[Red Hat]], [[IBM]] and [[Dell]]. Still, the vast majority of the [[Linux distribution]]s, including those developed by members of the Free Standards Group, do not follow this proposed standard 100%. In particular, paths specifically created by the FHS editors, such as /srv/, do not see widespread usage.
The FHS is maintained by the [[Free Standards Group]], a non-profit organization consisting of major software and hardware vendors, such as [[HP]], [[Red Hat]], [[IBM]] and [[Dell]]. Still, the vast majority of the [[Linux distribution]]s, including those developed by members of the Free Standards Group, do not follow this proposed standard 100%. In particular, paths specifically created by the FHS editors, such as /srv/, do not see widespread usage.
â
Some Linux systems, such as [[GoboLinux]], reject the FHS in favor of a different approach. Since the FHS began as a Linux initiative, most other UNIX and [[Unix-like]] operating systems completely ignore it in favor of their own systems,{{Fact|date=October 2008}} some of which differ greatly from the standard. For example, [[Mac OS X]] uses more readable names such as /Library/, /Applications/, and /Users/ in tandem with its traditional UNIX directory hierarchy.
+
Some Linux systems, such as [[GoboLinux]], use a different approach. Since the FHS began as a Linux initiative, most other UNIX and [[Unix-like]] operating systems completely ignore it in favor of their own systems,{{Fact|date=October 2008}} some of which differ greatly from the standard. For example, [[Mac OS X]] uses more readable names such as /Library/, /Applications/, and /Users/ in tandem with its traditional UNIX directory hierarchy.
Linux includes a /sys/ directory. [[Plan 9 from Bell Labs]] includes a /net/ directory.
Linux includes a /sys/ directory. [[Plan 9 from Bell Labs]] includes a /net/ directory.
